abstract: Members of the four-person criminal ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Léger and Max Ernst, were sentenced to a total of 15 years in prison.
snippet: Members of the four-person criminal ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Léger and Max Ernst, were sentenced to a total of 15 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A group of art forgers who sold falsely attributed oil paintings to art collectors, and whose victims included the comedian Steve Martin, were sentenced on Thursday by a court in Cologne, Germany, Bloomberg News reported. Wolfgang Beltracchi, the leader of the ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Léger and Max Ernst, was given a six-year sentence; his wife, Helene, was sentenced to four years while her sister, Jeanette, received a 21-month suspended sentence. Otto Schulte-Kellinghaus, a fourth member of the ring, was sentenced to five years.

headline.main: Art Forgers Whose Victims Included Steve Martin are Sentenced
